Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusing Data-Enabled Active Learning in Mathematics and Statistics Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Recent advances in technology are generating data on a scale never seen before - a phenomenon known as "big data". Industry demands workers that can retrieve useful information from very complex, unstructured data. Alabama State University will implement a Targeted Infusion Project entitled: Infusing Data-Enabled Active Learning in Mathematics and Statistics Courses. Project objectives are to adapt methods for big data analytics in mathematics courses; integrate big data analytics in existing courses; create a stand-alone course dedicated to the mathematics of big data analytics; develop and test instructional materials; collect and analyze achievement of outcomes based on student and industry feedback; and disseminate materials to other HBCUs and to the mathematical community.

This project will provide a better understanding of how big data analytics can be integrated within a classroom environment. The results obtained will translate into a framework of pedagogy and materials required for teaching big data analytics in mathematics courses. Several issues will be addressed that can add to the knowledge base in the field. These include the need for integrating big data analytics in mathematics courses; the need for support materials that can be used with a variety of textbooks; the impact of courses that include big data analytics on student learning and employment; and the impact of involving students in cross-disciplinary research teams to solve real big data problems. An online community portal will provide a means of dissemination, communication, and community involvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: This project aims to advance the state of undergraduate mathematics education by adapting and integrating Bigdata analytics in mathematics courses. Industry demands workers that can retrieve useful information from very complex, unstructured data. The mathematics courses offered at Alabama State University (ASU) help students develop the logical thinking and problem-solving skills while the statistics courses introduce students to methods of collection, organization, analysis, and interpretation of data. However, Bigdata analytics requires new mathematical and statistical methods and algorithms developed specifically for use with Bigdata.

Objectives: 1) Adapt methods for Bigdata analytics in mathematics courses, 2) Integrate Bigdata analytics in existing courses, 3) Create a stand-alone course dedicated to the mathematics of Bigdata analytics, 4) Develop and test instructional material, 5) Collect and analyze achievement of outcome based on student and industry feedback, and 6) Disseminate materials to other HBCUs and to the mathematical community at large.

Major Activities: In this project, we constructed, taught, and assessed a capstone course and 31 course modules that immerse students in real-world Bigdata practices through active learning. Our course walked students through producing a working solution by having them use Bigdata modules developed specifically to apply cutting-edge industry techniques at each point in the project lifecycle. The process was taught incrementally throughout the course by adding a lifecycle activity each week. Students worked in an interactive environment in which they were instructed on new techniques and then mentored in the use of those techniques through a series of hands-on exercises.

Intellectual Merit: This project provided a better understanding of how Bigdata analytics can be integrated within a classroom environment. The results obtained were translated into a framework of pedagogy and materials required for teaching Bigdata analytics in mathematics courses. Several research issues were addressed which were not seen in the literature. These include 1) the need for integrating Bigdata analytics in mathematics courses, 2) the need for support materials that can be used with a variety of textbooks, 3) the impact of courses that include Bigdata analytics on student learning and employment, and 4) the impact of involving students in cross-disciplinary research teams to solve real Bigdata problems.

Broader Impact: This project had a significant impact on how mathematics courses were taught and how students learn Bigdata concepts in these courses. The development of learning materials and teaching strategies were guided through the participation of faculty from diverse institutions, including high schools, two-year and four-year colleges and from industrial practitioners. This project significantly enhanced the capacity of ASU, an HBCU, to perform nationally recognized research in Bigdata education. Education accomplishments were disseminated through several channels: 1) Journal and conference publications; 2) Presentation in student symposiums; 3) Outreach activities of open house, lab tours, and seminars. In addition to that, 150 students were directly impacted during a four-year period. This student population was primarily comprised of under-represented minorities and female undergraduate students.

Major Outcomes

1.New Bigdata course and course modules: We have developed a new Bigdata capstone course and 31 Bigdata course modules for Linear Algebra, Discrete Mathematics, Differential Equations, Probability and Statistics, and Modern Geometry. These modules are likely to make an impact on how undergraduate math courses are taught in US universities. 

2.Student knowledge and confidence: The student feedback/survey results indicate that the sequence of topics would allow students to experience the benefit of working in a disciplined fashion. Students seeing the benefits of their studies in terms of Bigdata infused mathematics and Bigdata analytics projects provide practical experience for the students.

3.URM training: Over 150 URM STEM students have been exposed to Bigdata training.

4.Community workshops: We offered two in-person Bigdata workshop and one virtual-Bootcamp to the educational community.

5.Undergraduate students' research: From this project URM and women students were able to conduct undergraduate research under the guidance of the PI Dr.Pettis and Co-PI Dr.Swamidurai in the Bigdata Analytics Lab and 6 students have published their works in peer-reviewed conferences. 

6.Faculty Development: This project provided Bigdata training to 8 ASU faculty members.

7.STEM interdisciplinary research initiative: In summer 2020, our STEM interdisciplinary faculty team (faculty from mathematics, statistics, software engineering, physics, and biomedical engineering) worked on developing and testing active learning modules in engineering and physics courses designed to engross students in the process of advanced manufacturing principles and techniques.

8.Bigdata Analytics lab: This project has provided initial funding to set up a Bigdata Analytics lab specifically dedicated to teaching Bigdata analytics.

9.Students peer-teaching opportunity and retention: Through the efforts of this project, we were able to place talented seniors in a student-driven support lab as peer tutors. These student workers helped the retention efforts of the unit by providing STEM tutoring and aid with Bigdata projects.

10.Publications: With the support of this project 12 peer-reviewed papers were published.
